name: Kepler-220
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-220 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-220 is a star with 0.57 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.67 times its radius. It is located 560.86 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-220 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-220 b

Kepler-220 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.16 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-220.

The mass of Kepler-220 b is 0.58 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-220 b is 0.81 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-220 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-220 c

Kepler-220 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 9.03 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-220.

The mass of Kepler-220 c is 2.84 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-220 c is 1.57 that of Earth. At 2.84 Earth masses, Kepler-220 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-220 d

Kepler-220 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 28.12 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-220.

The mass of Kepler-220 d is 0.91 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-220 d is 0.98 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-220 d is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-220 e

Kepler-220 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.23 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 45.90 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-220.

The mass of Kepler-220 e is 1.92 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-220 e is 1.33 that of Earth. At 1.92 Earth masses, Kepler-220 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

With a semi-major axis of 0.226 astronomical units, and a mass of 1.92 Earth masses, Kepler-220 e could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-220, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
